Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Hot Springs Village Site: a Window to Southern Bering Sea Paleo-Ecosystems and Human - Landscape Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The southern Bering Sea and Bristol Bay are home to the United States? most important fisheries. Understanding the southern Bering Sea ecosystem is so critical to our understanding of climate change, global economic development, and modern fisheries that a number of US agencies have invested considerable resources to understand the Bering Sea ecosystem. Yet little is known about the ancient history of the Bering Sea, with no baseline from which to measure any modern changes. This collaborative project will undertake excavations at precisely identified locations in temporally distinct middens at the Hot Springs site, Port Moller, Alaskan Peninsula. Hot Springs has been excavated repeatedly in the past but poorly documented. It is one of the largest, if not the largest, village site on the Bering Sea coast, the northernmost known Aleut village, and a potential place for Aleut/Alutiiq interaction or occupation. On these grounds, alone, it is worth re-investigating to understand better regional prehistory. However, the PIs will also investigate major archaeological and ecological questions in the Bering Sea region, including human use of landscapes, stability and change in subsistence practices, species distribution, long-term climate change, and sea ice regimes. The project will add much to our understanding of human ecodynamic systems in the southeastern Bering Sea region, as well as including education and training for local Aleut students.

What makes this project most important is that the site was occupied during some of the warmest climatic regimes of the last 5000 years, often during time periods when the rest of the Alaska Peninsula shows a sparse population. It is at the southern edge of the winter ice pack but has deep and stratified shellfish deposits from 4000 years of human harvesting. Over 100 taxa of mammals, birds, fish, and shellfish have been identified in the Hot Springs deposits. Using systematic and targeted excavations to collect large samples of faunal remains from the Hot Springs Village site, the PIs will reconstruct the environmental history of the southern Bering Sea with the potential to create a baseline for modern fisheries studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The southern Bering Sea and Bristol Bay are home to one of the most important fisheries in the modern world system, and the sustainability of those fisheries, and the structure of the greater Bering Sea ecosystem, has been the focus of hundreds of studies. However, other than a few lake and ocean core studies, the southeastern Bering Sea exists as a deep-time data vacuum, with no baseline from which to measure any modern changes. This project is creating a 3500 year-long shifting baseline of nearshore ecosystems that includes fish, sea mammals, and birds.

Our group completed small, targeted archaeological excavations at the Hot Springs Village Site in Port Moller, on the northern side of the Alaska Peninsula in 2014. Knowing that each area of the site was occupied at different times, we focused on excavating middens in several places across the village site. In addition to cataloging the newly excavated materials,  multiple collections from over 50 years of excavations were transferred to the University of Alaska Museum of the North (UAMN) and are now being accessioned at UAMN. This is a massive undertaking. To date, the two largest collections (Hot Springs Village and Sanak Island) have been accessioned and can be found on the Arctos database which is freely searchable. These collections provide a significant resource to the University of Alaska Museum of the North's Archaeology collections and to researchers worldwide. The Hot Springs collection from Port Moller, along with the Sanak Island’s collections and others from the Alaska Peninsula, adds a unique collection from the coastlines of southern Alaska to UAMN.

Over 370,000 individual specimens make up the assemblage of the Hot Springs site. The makeup of this assemblage is overwhelmingly fish at 78% followed by 12% marine mammal, 6% terrestrial mammal, and 4% bird species; with a total of 67 different species identified across the four animal classes. Radiocarbon dates analyzed for this project show that these fauna represent three distinct time periods (3400-2450, 2000-1400, and 1250-1000 cal BP), providing a unique opportunity to compare and contrast the assemblage from each.

  • Terrestrial mammal species are represented equally across the three time periods.
  • There is a larger representation of walrus from 3400 to 2450 cal BP, which falls in line with previous studies showing this to be a colder period in time when a larger distribution of sea ice would have made walrus more available to people living at the Hot Springs site.
  • There is an increase in duck representation through time, a decrease in murres and puffins through time, and a large representation of cormorants from 2000 to 1450 cal BP, which are patterns that all warrant further investigation.
  • There is a high number of smelt and cod for the 3400 to 2450 cal BP time period, a higher percentage of flat fish for the 2000-1400 cal BP time period, and an increase in salmon from 1250 to 1050 cal BP, which are also patterns that warrant further investigation.
  • Stable isotope data is available for 378 individual fish (multiple species and each individual is accompanied by size estimates), 330 birds (multiple species), and 138 individual mammals (marine and terrestrial species). This data, combined with the analyses above will help illuminate the changes already weathered along the Peninsula in the past.

All together 10 undergraduate students and 4 graduate students received training and mentorship during this award. Four of the undergraduate students have gone on to graduate schools across the country. Undergraduate student participation was important throughout this project with students giving presentations, as well as completing capstone (thesis) projects and papers (n=2). In addition, one undergraduate student has prepared a manuscript to be submitted to a peer-reviewed journal.

This project funded 23 researchers, including graduate students and early career scholars from the Paleoecology of Subarctic and Arctic Seas working group, to attend the Oceans Past Initiative Conference. From these conference papers, a Special Edition of Quaternary Research was devised and to date seven of those have been published. Two more journal articles specifically focused on Hot Springs are in preparation. In addition, several more conference presentations and posters were given at anthropological meetings, fisheries meetings, and ecology meetings.

By measuring long-term ecosystem change and comparing this to the recent period of global change and exploitation by humans, this project will give managers of all types information to aid in their conservation, restoration, and commercial use efforts at the ecosystem level. Now that collections are returned to Alaska, local communities and stakeholders can more easily access them. This increased accessibility to the collections and any research results can foster ties to traditional practices, resource use, and age groups, helping to strengthen social and individual health and well-being within communities. This project has also strengthened partnerships and continued to provide outreach to local schools and community groups.
